G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 28A, 29, a.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 28A, 29, and 31, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this is a proceeding to modify an existing custody and parenting time judgment concerning a minor child of the parties.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 28A, 29, and 31, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this is a proceeding to modify an existing custody and parenting time judgment concerning a minor child of the parties.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 6.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 6 and applicable provisions of G.L. c. 215, because the prior judgment was entered in this Court, the parties and child reside within the Commonwealth, and the Middlesex Division has continuing jurisdiction over this family.

G.L. c. 215.proposition: Venue is proper in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 6 and applicable provisions of G.L. c. 215, because the prior judgment was entered in this Court, the parties and child reside within the Commonwealth, and the Middlesex Division has continuing jurisdiction over this family.

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 266–67 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: While the Child’s expressed preference is not dispositive, it is an important factor the Court may consider in determining her best interests, particularly at her current age and developmental stage.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly notes that the child expressed a preference to reside primarily with his mother, cites Ardizoni v. Raymond for the rule that a child’s preference is not dispositive of custody, and nonetheless treats that preference as a meaningful factor suggesting he could readjust to living with her. This shows the court recognizes a child’s stated preference as an important, though not controlling, consideration in the best-interests analysis, consistent with the claimed proposition, even though the opinion does not dwell on age/developmental stage in detail.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “In addition, we note that Caleb expressed to the guardian ad litem at the outset of the investigation his preference to reside primarily with his mother, and he reiterated this preference at the conclusion of the investigation, shortly before trial. Although not dispositive of the custody issue, Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738-739 (1996), these factors, at the very least, suggest that Caleb might quickly readjust to living with his mother during the week, and visiting his father on weekends and during part of each school vacation.”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738–39 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: While the Child’s expressed preference is not dispositive, it is an important factor the Court may consider in determining her best interests, particularly at her current age and developmental stage.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses that a child’s expression of custody preference is a permissible factor in a best-interests analysis but is not decisive, especially for younger children. The court faults the trial judge for giving the children’s preferences excessive weight, while affirming that such preferences remain one of many relevant considerations. This directly aligns with the proposition that the child’s preference, while not dispositive, is an important factor the court may consider.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The list also allows the judge to consider the expressions of a preference by a child in a custody dispute… Statements of a particular preference, however, ‘must be treated with caution’… Although one of the many permissible factors to be considered, the preference of a younger child ‘is not given decisive weight.’ Bak v. Bak, supra at 617. See also Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 599 n.11 (1996) (‘[Preference of an eleven-year-old is not given decisive weight, although it is a factor to be considered’).”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: The combination of Mother’s substantially improved stability and availability, her appropriate housing with a dedicated bedroom for the Child, the Child’s maturation and clearly expressed wishes, and the Child’s emotional reaction to the current schedule, together with Father’s refusal to adjust the schedule, constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances warranting modification of the 2017 Judgment under Massachusetts law.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.proposition: The combination of Mother’s substantially improved stability and availability, her appropriate housing with a dedicated bedroom for the Child, the Child’s maturation and clearly expressed wishes, and the Child’s emotional reaction to the current schedule, together with Father’s refusal to adjust the schedule, constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances warranting modification of the 2017 Judgment under Massachusetts law.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an initial custody determination and the necessity of explicit findings about domestic violence and its effects on the child. It does not address modification of a prior custody judgment, the standard for a material and substantial change in circumstances, or the specific types of changes (parent’s improved stability, housing, child’s maturation and wishes, schedule issues) described in the proposition. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the claimed Massachusetts modification standard or that this constellation of factors constitutes a material change.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.relevant_excerpt: "Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above."

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 899–900 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The combination of Mother’s substantially improved stability and availability, her appropriate housing with a dedicated bedroom for the Child, the Child’s maturation and clearly expressed wishes, and the Child’s emotional reaction to the current schedule, together with Father’s refusal to adjust the schedule, constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances warranting modification of the 2017 Judgment under Massachusetts law.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion deals with standards for an initial custody determination and emphasizes that all relevant factors must be weighed under the best-interests standard. It does not address what constitutes a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ for modification of an existing judgment, nor does it discuss factors like a parent’s improved stability, new housing, the child’s maturation or stated preferences, or a parent’s refusal to adjust a schedule as grounds for modification. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific modification proposition stated.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed… The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 31, in making orders about custody and parenting time, “the rights of the parents shall, in the absence of misconduct, be held to be equal” and “the happiness and welfare of the children shall determine their custody.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.proposition: The controlling consideration is always the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses and reaffirms the “best interests of the child” standard as the governing principle in custody determinations. It traces the doctrine’s historical roots and cites prior Massachusetts cases stating that the children’s best interests or welfare are the paramount concern in such disputes. Although the case is in the context of nonmarital children and G.L. c. 209C, it clearly endorses best interests as the controlling consideration in custody cases generally.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas… (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.raw_text: Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 Mass. 704, 711 (1984)
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.proposition: The controlling consideration is always the best interests of the child.
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the dispositional decision in care and protection cases in terms of the children’s best interests, explaining that parental fitness and best interests are intertwined and that, beyond determining unfitness, the judge must decide among placement options based on what will further the children’s best interests. It also quotes G.L. c. 119, § 26, emphasizing that the court may make “any other appropriate order ... as may conduce to his best interests,” showing that best interests is the controlling consideration once the court is determining disposition. Thus the case supports the proposition that the controlling consideration is the child’s best interests.
Care & Protection of Three Minors, 392 M.relevant_excerpt:
“This court has said that the ‘parental fitness’ test and the ‘best interests of the child’ test are not mutually exclusive, but rather ‘reflect different degrees of emphasis on the same factors.’ … In this case, the judge’s task was not complete once he had determined that the mother should not have custody of her children. Also, he should have addressed the various placement options which would further the children’s best interests….”

And quoting § 26: the judge may “make any other appropriate order with reference to the care and custody of the child as may conduce to his best interests.”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546\u2.proposition: In determining whether to modify custody or parenting time, the Court must find both (a) a material change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (b) that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546\u2.support_reasoning: The quoted portion is a concurrence focused on statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and on relocation/removal when only one parent is a legal parent. It critiques the Probate and Family Court judge’s handling of relocation and emphasizes the statutory custody framework under G.L. c. 209C, § 10, but it does not set out or apply a two-prong ‘material change in circumstances plus best interests’ standard for modification of an existing custody or parenting-time judgment. Any such proposition would have to come from another part of the opinion or another case, not from this text.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546\u2.relevant_excerpt: After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003)...

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865, 871–72 (2006)
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: In determining whether to modify custody or parenting time, the Court must find both (a) a material change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (b) that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly interprets G.L. c. 208, § 28 and states that a modification judgment regarding care and custody may be entered only if the court finds both (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the earlier judgment, and (2) that the modification is necessary in the best interests of the children. The court then applies that two-part standard to the mother’s removal/modification request, correcting the trial judge for misapplying the ‘changed circumstances’ requirement, thereby directly supporting the claimed proposition.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: He concluded from this that any change in circumstances occurred prior to the divorce, and therefore did not justify a modification. His ruling is inconsistent with G. L. c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, § 60 ("Upon a complaint after a divorce . . . , the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children").

Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App.raw_text: Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App. Ct. 918, 920 (2005)
Rosenwasser v. Rosenwasser, 63 Mass. App.proposition: Regular and meaningful parenting time with both parents generally promotes a child’s best interests, stability, and emotional development, absent countervailing factors such as abuse or neglect.

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–05 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: Regular and meaningful parenting time with both parents generally promotes a child’s best interests, stability, and emotional development, absent countervailing factors such as abuse or neglect.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly endorses the general value of a child’s frequent and continuing contact with both parents and states that children are usually better off when both parents share responsibility and physical custody, which matches the proposition’s focus on regular and meaningful parenting time. Although the court ultimately limits the father’s visitation due to case-specific conflict and concerns, it does so as an exception grounded in the best interests standard, thereby treating robust contact with both parents as the general rule absent countervailing factors. This aligns with the claimed proposition’s “generally promotes” and “absent countervailing factors” qualifiers.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the precept that ‘the law sees a value in “frequent and continuing contact” of the child[ren] with both . . . parents.’ … Children are entitled to the love, companionship and concern of both parents, and they usually are better off if the parents can agree to share in the responsibility of their rearing as well as in physical custody.”

Jones v. Jones, 349 Mass. 259, 263 (1965.proposition: The Child’s therapist’s reported view that expanded time with Mother, including overnights, would alleviate the Child’s distress and guilt surrounding departures underscores that the requested modification would promote the Child’s emotional welfare.
Jones v. Jones, 349 Mass. 259, 263 (1965.support_reasoning: The case concerns post-divorce modification of custody from a parent to a grandparent and the court’s authority and standards for altering a foreign custody decree. It does not discuss a child’s therapist, therapeutic opinions, or how expanded parenting time or overnights with a parent might alleviate a child’s emotional distress or guilt. The cited page focuses on changed circumstances and the general welfare standard, not on therapeutic recommendations or increased time with a parent as promoting emotional welfare, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Jones v. Jones, 349 Mass. 259, 263 (1965.relevant_excerpt: “We concur in the conclusion of the judge that the ‘happiness and welfare of Wendolyn require that she be in the custody of … Elsa.’ ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ … The uprooting of a child of tender years in these circumstances should be done only for compelling reasons.”

Cooper v. Keto, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 798, 8.raw_text: Cooper v. Keto, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 798, 803–04 (2013)
Cooper v. Keto, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 798, 8.proposition: Mother seeks only that the schedule be updated to reflect the current realities of the family, as the law contemplates when there has been a material change in circumstances.
Cooper v. Keto, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 798, 8.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Cooper v. Keto is a concurring opinion focused on the disproportionate legal fees and a general admonition that litigation should be a last resort. It does not address modification of a parenting or visitation schedule, nor does it discuss the legal standard of a material change in circumstances or the law’s contemplation of updating schedules to reflect current family realities. Therefore, this excerpt does not support the stated proposition.
Cooper v. Keto, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 798, 8.relevant_excerpt: "Litigation should be the last option, not the first. To that end, it is often beneficial to the parties, and counsel in advising their clients, to step back and take stock of what the case is about, what has gone on before, and what may lie ahead. In devising the judicial playbook, one should not forget the pocketbook."

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 and 31.proposition: Under the totality of the circumstances, including the factors described above and the statutory standard under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31, it is in the Child’s best interests that the 2017 Judgment be modified to provide for increased and regular overnight parenting time with Mother and a more balanced residential schedule.
